tit.e: Fukujinzuke (pickle of seven kinds of vegetables)
tit.cmt: カッコ部分を補いました。
tit.e: Fukujinzuke (pickle of seven kinds of vegetables)

sen.j: 福神漬（ふくじんづけ、「ふくしんづけ」と呼ぶ地方も多い。）
sen.e: Fukujinzuke (or fukusinnzuke depending on regions) (literally, pickles of the gods of good fortune) is a kind of non-fermented pickles.
Fukujinzuke (or fukusinnzuke depending on regions) (literally, pickles of the gods of good fortune).

sen.e: Fukujinzuke (or fukusinnzuke depending on regions) (literally, pickles of the gods of good fortune).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 非発酵型の漬物の一種で、ダイコン、ナス、ナタマメ（鉈豆）、レンコン、キュウリ、シソの実、シイタケまたは白ゴマなどの7種の野菜類を細かく刻み、醤油と砂糖やみりんで作った調味液で漬けたもの。
sen.e: It consists of seven vegetables such as daikon radish, eggplant, sword bean, lotus root, cucumber, perilla seeds, shiitake mushroom, or white sesame, which are sliced and pickled in liquid preparation containing soy sauce and sugar or mirin (sweet cooking rice wine).

It is a kind of non-fermented pickles, and consists of seven vegetables such as daikon radish, eggplant, sword bean, lotus root, cucumber, perilla seeds, shiitake mushroom, or white sesame, which are finely chopped and pickled in the flavored liquid containing soy sauce and sugar or mirin (sweet cooking rice wine).
sen.cmt: 前列からの修正に伴い修正、スペースの修正をしました。sliced→finely chopped,liquid preparation→the flavored liquid と修正しました。
sen.e: It is a kind of non-fermented pickles, and consists of seven vegetables such as daikon radish, eggplant, sword bean, lotus root, cucumber, perilla seeds, shiitake mushroom, or white sesame, which are finely chopped and pickled in the flavored liquid containing soy sauce and sugar or mirin (sweet cooking rice wine).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 明治時代以降、国民食として短期間に全国に広まった最大の理由は、帝国陸海軍の隊内食・戦闘食の副食として採用されたため、兵役終了後の元兵士達により、その味が全国の家庭に持ち帰られ、浸透した。
sen.e: The major reason why fukujinzuke had become popular nationwide rapidly from the Meiji period as a national food is that fukujinzuke was introduced by the Imperial Army and Navy as subsidiary food for rations at barrack and combat, and the retired military personnel brought the taste of fukujinzuke into their home, then it has been spread.

The most reason why fukujinzuke had become popular nationwide rapidly from the Meiji period as a national food, is that fukujinzuke was introduced by the Imperial Army and Navy as a subsidiary food for rations in barracks and combat, and the retired soldiers brought the taste of fukujinzuke back to their homes, then spread.
sen.cmt: major→most,カンマ、a を挿入しました。at barrack→in barracks,military personnel→soldiers,into their home→back to their homes,it has been spread→spread と修正しました。

sen.j: いろいろな野菜が入っていること、また店が上野不忍池の弁才天近くにあったこと、更には「ご飯のお供にこれさえあれば他におかずは要らず、食費が抑えられ金がたまる（＝家に七福神がやってきたかのような幸福感）」という解釈で、作家の梅亭金鵞が名付けたという説もある。
sen.e: About the origin of the name fukujinzuke, followings are said that because it contains various kinds of vegetable, that because the shop was near the shrine deifying Benzaiten (the Goddess of Eloquence, Music, and Art) at the Shinobazu-no-Ike pond in Ueno, or that a writer Kinga BAITEI named it because no other subsidiary for rice are needed so long as fukujinzuke is their, then food cost would be saved and it is happy as if the Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck) had come to home.

sen.j: これは大正時代(明治35,6年説あり）に日本郵船が周航していた欧州航路客船で、一等船客にカレーライスを供する際に添えられたのが最初であり、それが日本中に広まったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the first time fukujinzuke served with curry and rice was in the Taisho period (another theory says its in 1902 or 1903) for the first class passengers of the passenger ship on a European run of the Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK Line), then spread all over Japan.
